definition: The **Cockcroft-Gault equation** estimates creatinine clearance (CrCl) as a surrogate for glomerular filtration rate (GFR). It accounts for age, weight, sex, and serum creatinine to estimate kidney function. This formula is widely used for **drug dosing adjustments** in patients with renal impairment.
clinical_usage: **Drug dosing**: Most medication package inserts use Cockcroft-Gault for renal dose adjustments
**Screening for CKD**: Quick bedside estimate of kidney function
**Monitoring progression**: Track changes in kidney function over time
**Pre-operative assessment**: Evaluate renal function before surgery or contrast administration
limitations: Less accurate at extremes of body weight (obesity, cachexia)
Not validated for acute kidney injury (requires stable creatinine)
Uses actual body weight, which can overestimate in obesity
CKD-EPI equation is preferred for CKD staging by KDIGO guidelines
pearls: Remember: **Female sex factor is 0.85** (women have less muscle mass → less creatinine production)
Creatinine is in the **denominator** → higher Cr = lower GFR (inverse relationship)
Age is subtracted from 140 → GFR naturally declines with age
For drug dosing, Cockcroft-Gault is still the standard despite newer equations
A GFR <60 for >3 months = **Chronic Kidney Disease** by definition

sources.title: Cockcroft DW, Gault MH. Prediction of creatinine clearance from serum creatinine. Nephron. 1976;16(1):31-41
KDIGO 2012 Clinical Practice Guideline for the Evaluation and Management of Chronic Kidney Disease
FDA Guidance: Pharmacokinetics in Patients with Impaired Renal Function
